result.execSummary:
The defendant Morgan Kay Nee was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Disorderly Conduct [Modifiers: Domestic Abuse], a class B misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 947.01(1).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

miscConds.notes:
If Probation is revoked and sent to jail or discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of restitution victims and/or governmental entities for the balance due. All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.
If revoked and sent to prison, DOC shall withhold 25% of all inmates monies to pay fines/costs with the balance due as a condition of extended supervision/parole.

Not to consume alcoholic beverages, illegal drugs or possess drug paraphernalia. 
Not to be on the premises of any tavern or business whose sole purpose is the sale of alcoholic beverages. 
No violent or abusive contact with victim 1 or juveniles in general.
Not possess controlled substances except for those medications specifically prescribed for him/her by a health care professional. 
Not to possess needles/syringes except with a valid prescription. 
No criminal conduct.
Not associate with those who possess illegal controlled substances. 
No non-prescribed drugs or alcohol while taking care of children or around children.

Counseling/assessments/treatment deemed appropriate by agent; including a mental health assessment and follow through. 
Provide DNA sample and be responsible for the cost.
Attend parenting classes.
Take all recommended meds.

Good faith effort to seek/maintain employment. 
Attend school.
Expungement under 973.015 upon; Successful completion of probation.

judgments.action: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

charges.dispoDesc: Guilty Due to No Contest Plea

result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Morgan Kay Nee

records.addlTxt: Count 2.

4:28 PM Defendant Morgan Kay Nee appeared by video.  Attorney Solomon H Gatton appeared by video for Morgan Kay Nee.  Prosecuting attorney Joel N Urmanski in court for the State of Wisconsin. V1 in court. Defendant waives right to in person appearance. Plea questionnaire/waiver of rights efiled. Court does plea colloquy w/deft. Defendant enters a NC plea to count 2. Count 1 DRI. Victim made a statement. State puts the agreement on the record. State is not objecting to expungement. Joint recommendation. Defendant makes a statement. Court orders 2 years probation on count 2. Count 1 DRI. Court grants expungement upon successful completion of probation.

1:59 PM Defendant Morgan Kay Nee appeared by video.  Attorney Solomon H Gatton in court for Morgan Kay Nee.  Attorney Joel N Urmanski appeared by video for State of Wisconsin.  Atty Gatton has spoken to the deft regarding day report. Defendant is still searching for stable housing. Defense states there is a wait list for treatment. Rogers not allowing admission due to insurance barrier. DA's office has provided an offer today to defense. Court admonishes the defendant. Father of Morgan's children makes request to amend condition of bond for Morgan to watch the children for the father to attend medical appointments in Milwaukee at the VA. Court could schedule bond hearing in short order if the state requests contact condition be amended. No written notice needed, state to contact JA. Court will address bond at next hearing no matter what. Per defense, they are very close to resolution.
